title: How to Connect a MacBook to an iMac: 2 Step-by-Step Methods

steps.title: Determine the cable you’ll need for your iMac.
steps.content: Determine the cable you’ll need for your iMac. The type of cable you’ll need varies by model: [1] X Research source iMac 27-inch (2009): Mini DisplayPort to Mini DisplayPort cable. iMac 27-inch (2010): Mini DisplayPort to Mini DisplayPort cable. iMac (2011 to mid 2014): Thunderbolt or Thunderbolt 2 cable. iMac models from late 2014 (the Retina 5k model) and later can’t be used as displays.

steps.title: Locate the port on your MacBook.
steps.content: Locate the port on your MacBook. If both the MacBook and iMac have the same port (Mini DisplayPort or Thunderbolt), you won’t need to purchase an adapter. If your MacBook has a Thunderbolt 3 (USB-C) port, you’ll need a Thunderbolt 3 (USB-C) to Thunderbolt 2 adapter. [2] X Research source See Apple’s Mac port guide to learn how to identify your ports.

steps.title: Turn on both computers.
steps.content: Turn on both computers. If you haven’t yet logged in to either computer, you should do so now. [3] X Research source If you want to clean your monitors before connecting the Macs, wait until after cleaning to turn them on. Same for cleaning the keyboard .

steps.title: Connect the Mini DisplayPort or Thunderbolt cable to both computers.
steps.content: Connect the Mini DisplayPort or Thunderbolt cable to both computers. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Press ⌘ Command+F2 on the iMac.
steps.content: Press ⌘ Command + F2 on the iMac. The iMac’s display will now show the MacBook’s screen instead of its own. [5] X Research source You've successfully connected your MacBook to your iMac! If you're looking for more connection information, check out how to connect an external hard drive to your MacBook .

steps.title: Connect both Macs to the same wireless network.
steps.content: Connect both Macs to the same wireless network. This method allows you to share files wirelessly . If you don’t have a wireless network, you can use an Ethernet cable instead (just connect the cable to an Ethernet port on both computers, and then move to the next step). Here’s how to connect both computers to Wi-Fi: [6] X Research source If you see near the top-right corner of the screen, click it, and then select Turn Wi-Fi On . Click at the top-right corner of the screen. Select a network. Enter the password and click Join .

steps.title: Click the menu on the computer that has something to share.
steps.content: Click the menu on the computer that has something to share. It’s at the top-left corner of the screen. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Click System Preferences.
steps.content: Click System Preferences . This will open the System Preferences settings in a new window. This is called System Settings in macOS Ventura and later.

steps.title: Click Sharing.
steps.content: Click Sharing . A list of sharing services will appear. In macOS Ventura and later, you'll need to click General in the sidebar to access the Sharing option.

steps.title: Set up file sharing.
steps.content: Set up file sharing. Here’s how to allow users of the other computer to access the files on this one: Click File Sharing to turn it on. Click + under the folder list. Select a folder and click Add . Anyone with an account on this Mac can access it from the other computer. If you want to restrict access to certain users, select the folder, click + under the user list, then select who should have access. You can add users with local accounts (regular logins you set up on this Mac) or by Apple ID by selecting them from your contacts. Make note of the IP address on the Sharing screen. It should look like ″afp://10.0.0.1″ or ″smb://10.0.0.1″. Click Done to confirm the changes.

steps.title: Open Finder on the other Mac.
steps.content: Open Finder on the other Mac. It’ll be the first icon on the Dock, which is usually at the bottom of the screen. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Click the Go menu.
steps.content: Click the Go menu. It’s at the top of the screen.

steps.title: Enter the IP address for the other computer.
steps.content: Enter the IP address for the other computer. This is the address you found on the other computer’s Sharing screen.

steps.title: Choose how to connect.
steps.content: Choose how to connect. Select Registered User if you want to log into a local account on the other computer. Select Using an Apple ID to log in with your Apple ID. Select Guest if the files don’t require a login.

steps.title: Follow the on-screen instructions to log in.
steps.content: Follow the on-screen instructions to log in. Once you’ve connected to the other computer, you can access its files.

steps.title: Set up printer sharing (optional).
steps.content: Set up printer sharing (optional). If you’d like to share the printer from this computer, return to the Sharing settings, click Printer Sharing , and choose a printer. Once shared, you’ll be able to print to it from any app on the other computer by selecting the printer (and logging in, if prompted to do so). Anyone with an account on this computer can print by default. To select specific users, click + under the user list, then choose who should be allowed to print. If you're just getting started with your printer, check out our guide on setting up a wireless printer connection .

steps.title: Set up other types of sharing (optional).
steps.content: Set up other types of sharing (optional). If you want users of the other computer to be able to connect to this one for remote administration or screen sharing, choose one of those options from the list, then follow the same instructions as you did for file and printer sharing.
